summary: Singer David Bowie reinvents himself as Ziggy Stardust while touring America to promote his new album "The Man Who Sold the World."

reviews.content: Awful awful awful representation of Bowie and painful acting .
Ghastly production. Even the hair was bad. Very slow and lacked depth. I feel sorry for the actors.
I could only watch 20 minutes before turning it off. It's an offense to David Bowie.. and movie making in general.
Absolute bollocks...pretending to be something that he was never....Bowie was always driven and was always trying for success and fame...was not a lamp limp gimp that this movie portrays

I couldn't find anything to like about this movie. Johnny Flynn, though I like him in other things, is nothing like David Bowie. Nothing about this movie seemed true to life. It was pretty boring, and painful watching David Bowie be turned into this sad sack, entitled, jerk guy with an identity crisis and no communication skills. 

The lack of music speaks for itself. Skip this one.
Horrible movie, don't waste your time watching it!!!

This is a complete turd. How do you make a David Bowie movie without any of David Bowie's songs? My wife and I watched "Class Action Park" shortly after this and I joked, "I'll bet this movie has more Bowie songs than Stardust!" Wouldn't you know... closing credits of "Class Action Park," they play All The Madmen (by David Bowie). I was rolling on the floor laughing.

It looks like it was shot by a 2nd year cinematography student. Every other scene is a pensive Bowie gazing out of the window of a moving car. I'm sure 20 mins of the movie is this repeated over and over (and over).

I'm not saying you should give this a hard pass because it's one of the finest hate-watch movies ever. Don't expect anything and you will still be disappointed. But shout out to Marc Maron who seemed to be the only good thing about this movie.

Full of inaccuracies and piss poor screen writing and editing, this truly does a disservice to David Bowie as he didn't want a movie made about him for years, and also a sin for the great actors such as Mike Moran.

Stardust is the most lifeless attempt at capturing the early years of one of the greatest musicians ever! Although Johnny Flynn is alright as David Bowie, almost every other aspect takes away from his performance. Considering they didn't get permission from his family, this is a disgrace of a biopic and something you should stay far away from!

This movie covers a span of time in Bowie's career where he recorded:  'The Man Who Sold the World,' 'Changes,' 'Life on Mars?,' 'Queen Bitch,' 'Starman,' 'Ziggy Stardust,' 'Suffragette City,' 'Jean Genie,' & 'Moonage Daydream' to name a few.  And you won't hear any of those songs once.  Whatever you may think of 'Rocketman' or 'Bohemia Rhapsody' those filmmakers, at least, knew people expected to hear music.

This film will go down in history as one of the least musical biopics of one of the most musically influential subjects ever.  It's utterly mad.

Then there's the specter of schizophrenia which is a predominant theme in Bowie's music but is only explored in fragments in the movie.  At the end of the movie you see he's undergone this complete metamorphosis and you witness not one iota of his becoming Ziggy or anything akin to what we think of as Bowie.  

Johnny Flynn's portrayal is just simply nothing like Bowie at all.  Especially, as Bowie on stage.  He can't walk nor talk nor sing nor even wear clothes like Bowie.  He has not a clue as how to portray Bowie's theatrical aesthetic.  

The whole thing is just bloody terrible.

This movie is a shame. Stardust has failed from the beginning and it's a mess .I just can't understand how is this possible to let someone making  a biopic about David Bowie without his own music and relevant stories of his life.I found that this movie tried to simplify the genius behind the complex of Ziggy Stardust's creation.At multiple times,the film suffered of a lack creativity and budgeting.It feels like they did a terrible fan footage.I had good hopes for appreciate it,but I just can't be satisfied by the results.For me,Stardust is really inappropriate and should be better than that.
2 stars, 1 for costumes, 1 for set design. Congrats on those- too bad the rest of the movie was lacking character or interest. Props to Marc Maron for playing himself....again.

I tried I really did. Poor Marc. He was great. He was the only thing keeping me interested. This movie had no budget kinda like the storyline. I kept seeing the same exact cars in different places. The music chosen to open scenes was unnerving. What moron would keep essential paperwork scattered about in a car? 
 The main lead who played Bowie should have researched his role/character better if at all. He's one of those over reactive actors. Horrendous in every way. I haven't seen a movie this bad since Ishtar! I should've checked with my Bowie friends before I wasted my time. This is a warning. Don't waste your precious time.
Great movie! Maybe someday, it'll be more respected.

David Bowie was an Artist. This film was not artistic. David Bowie carried great cultural significance in his message and convictions. This film said nothing and caused me to drift off. David Bowie is still worshipped by many. This film was sacrilegious.

So the secret's out. This movie was about the poorly fashioned orange yarn wig from props that magically transformed Bowie into the alter ego Ziggy Stardust. The movie does nothing to flesh out the influences that inspired him to this end, or beginning. Instead the film makers hacked into Bowie's insecurities, inability to hold normal interviews, highlighting a lot of whining not to mention eye rolls from the press. It makes me wonder if the film makers who couldn't get the rights to Bowie's music were so sore that they pressed on without it and for kicks left a whole portion of the movie on the cutting room floor. And honestly, the absence of the music? What else will these guys come up with, "Dylan-no lyrics"...Can't wait.

Ignore the bad reviews because it is painfully obvious that those folks do not get David Bowie, his early struggles to break into major stardom, or his insecurities and fears about his family's (including his half brother Terry) history of mental illness.  This movie is a very thin slice of the David Bowie story, and probably not one many casual fans know about, or maybe even care to much to learn about?  Marc Maron is absolutely stunning as the late, great Ron Oberman,  the record label rep that took Bowie under his wing when he first came to the USA. Admittedly,  the movie didn't get the nod from the Bowie camp or feature lots of his big hit songs, but it is a wonderful little film that was extremely well done and worth seeing...It is truly staggering to me that this movie is not better reviewed...Do your homework on Bowie's early story,  manage your expectations that you are going to see something like the Queen or Elton flicks, and enjoy what is truly a terrific look at Bowie's progression to the Ziggy Stardust era of his career.   This movie deserves so much more praise than it is getting.

what a dull mess ! honestly, this snooze-fest is an abomination to the genius of who David Bowie is, the director is so out of his league on this 'pseudo-biopic' for a music legend such as Ziggy Stardust. Seriously, 'Bohemian Rhapsody' and 'Rocketman' have been far better executed than that movie, it make Gabriel Range look like a freaking amateur as he completely missed the mark, even on a shoestring budget. Obviously, Bowie's family has disavowed this feature film, so of course no original songs are spread out through out this boring flick. David Bowie fans should and must avoid this insult of a celluloid disaster at all cost.

There is something beautiful about this film  : it's about an artist finding himself, the relationship between creativity and mental health,  and the failures you endure to succeed. Ignore idiot critics : David's music would have made this even better, but it's a mark of how good it is that it works without it. Even if Marc Bolan looks like a cross between a tansvestite trucker and Bonny Prince Charlie.
Marc Maron was great in this movie
Total Meh. Main problem is just too old and uninspired main actor. Don't ask me to watch another Johnny Flynn movie.

This is an amazing film about one year in David Bowie's life, 1971, just before he became the iconic Ziggy Stardust. Johnny Flynn does a stunning job portraying the young Bowie. The story is about Bowie touring the USA with publicist Ron Oberman, attempting to promote his album under the most challenging circumstances. Bowie and Oberman have to work together to overcome the skepticism of David's album from the record company and the public. In facing these challenges and potential failure, we watch Bowie find his way, inventing and developing himself as an artist. Especially poignant are the scenes where David spends time with his brother, who faces the challenges of Schizophrenia. This is a thoughtful and sensitive portrayal of a turning point in an artist's life.

It's odd to me why this film ever got the green light.  Apparently nobody could afford the rights to any music... how could there be a Bowie biopic with no Bowie songs?!?! Flynn did not embody Bowie in the slightest, in any capacity.  There is just no content anywhere in this film that really has anything to do with Bowie at all...  again, I just have to wonder why this was made?

I feel that I must preface my review of Stardust by addressing the issue that Johnny Flynn did not fulfill the impossible tasks of mastering physical likeness to Bowie, or his mannerisms and body language, which any obsessed fan such as myself could plainly see when watching the film. I don't think producing a clone of Bowie to portray him in this film was the ultimate goal of the film maker's vision, and I'm sure they realized it was utterly impossible for anyone to share any kind of likeness that could fully portray even a Bowie-esque impersonation, so I'm sure the idea of attempting an accurate depiction of Bowie was likely scrapped before Johnny Flynn was casted to portray him. I am also fully aware that this film was not approved or endorsed by Bowie's family, and as a result the film maker did not obtain the rights to use Bowies music in the film and this very much concerned me before I saw the film Stardust, however I don't really feel like this took away from this impactful film. While I thought this was brilliant film, but it is essential for the viewer to abandon any expectations that it will somehow encapsulate the impact that Bowie's genius has had on art and pop culture. Stardust is not about Bowie the super-human icon, but the story about him as a mortal young man, as well as introducing the viewer to the people, experiences and aspects of his young life that were essential to the specific way in which he developed both as a person, as well as an artist. This film portrays the vulnerabilities and fears he faced at the beginning of his career, and how he overcame the self-confidence issues he had by developing a philosophy, and way of approaching artistic performance through fully immersing himself into the roles he created, and performed over many years of his artistic career. The is an emphasis on how Bowie did not compromise any of his creative vision in order to achieve fame, and thoughtfully portrays him in the process of establishing the framework from which all of his epic works were derived. Stardust is a film about Bowie overcoming ongoing barriers he was faced in his personal life, and finding his way as a human being, performer and artist before and during The Man Who Sold The World promotional tour in America. I think this film really humanized Bowie in an endearing way, with providing just a glimpse into how the public would come to know him as a super human Icon, and a larger than life icon and musical legend.

I really  think this film deserves way more credit than it's getting. Not only is it historically accurate (despite being fiction) in it's portrayal of David's complicated relationship with  His brother, but the various characters are played well, there's a sense of humor, and overall I enjoyed it very much.

Loved it!! Great insight into the genesis of Bowie...into David Jones.
Of course would have been nice to hear the songs , especially at the finale as Ziggy Stardust . But it doesn't take away from what the movie wants to say. Don't be discouraged by the negative reviews ,give it a chance. As a plus, Johnny Flynn is lovely to look at and to listen to when he sings 👍

A shameful film that shouldn't have appeared. The actor is completely different from Bowie and plays and sings disgustingly, there is no Bowie music in the film either, because it was made against the wishes of the Bowie family. Don't go to see this movie, it's even worse than you can imagine.

lacking the music of the genius bowie, and skipping over his best album ever made (arguably) this is a pretty decent film.  Portrayed as arriving 5 years too late for the British invasion and a weak fey sixties token, it missed the driving force of genius that made HUNKY DORY album before doing the less daring ZIGGY STARDUST record which catapulted the man to fame and stardom.  
For a documentary about a music icon without any of his music is pretty good, but it misses much more than the music, it misses the driving force of the man.

I was expecting total trash, but it wasn't. It would have been nice if the estate allowed the Man's music, and gave its blessings, this movie would have been far better if so. There are times when the camera captures Flynn and he looks like Bowie. That in itself was wholly satisfying for me.

It is sad when the most intriguing parts of a film are the vintage cars and hotel carpeting.

It's a shame the makers of this film ever invoked the name of David Bowie. It wasn't required by the script, and at the top of the film it is disclaimed as "mostly fiction."

Johnny Flynn as David Jones/Bowie presents an image I don't associate with Bowie: childish, kind of stupid, lacking direction or drive. We take a really long road trip with him and his road manager, and his flashbacks and daydreams add up to nothing much. I feel for Flynn. I think his role is poorly written and misdirected.

Mark Maron does a fine job as Oberman, Bowie's road manager. Perhaps the story would have been interesting told from hisp erspective -- what he saw and heard. Instead, the film tells about things it doesn't seem to know much about. It's mostly surface.

The parade of anecdotes lead nowhere, several music writers pass through to little effect.

Jena Malone delivers, but her wig is bad and distracting... and what happened to the big bump in her dress? I guess we'll never know. Nothing unites her character while pregnant with the slender post-birth iteration.

This film does not excel at complete ideas.

First, how many critics have made great, good, or even fair movies? How many of these critics knew Bowie personally and can really claim they have it right and not the movie?  Who really gives a fuck what critics say.  I took the movie less as a Bowie biopic and more of a story of how fucked up the music business is...and it accomplished that.


.

A David Bowie biopic with an actor who looks and sounds nothing like Bowie, and doesn't feature a single moment of the legend's music.

As biopics go, this is an abomination. Plain and simple.
This film stole precious moments and should be destroyed as it is a crime to filmmaking and the legacy of David Bowie.

A great performance by everyone in the cast. For a movie where you get a glimpse of a man and not just a song this is the movie for you. Many people forget that real things are the inspiration for fantastical pieces of art-this movie reminds us  that they are.

I think this was an interesting movie but not as good as it could've been. The performances were definitely good and tje scenes of David Bowie and Mark Oberman just talking are probably the best scenes in the movie. This wasn't a bad movie but with it being about such as influential and mesmerizing performer it lacks the magic you would expect from it. This is not as good as other biopic like "Rocketman" and "Bohemian Rhapsody" but it's definitely unique. I think it could've been a great movie if they were allowed to use David Bowie's music. I think that if this is a sequel set in the late 70s or mid 80s I think it could lead to some great scenes regarding the making of Under Pressure and David's work on the movie Labyrinth but this movie on it's own is a 6.5/10 but is definitely worth a watch.
Terribly written, horrible acting, doesn't look, sound or act like david bowie. None of his music is in this film. Horrible and wouldn't recommend to and other bowie fan

That's just awful that they made a biopic about somebody who and whose family DID NOT want this movie made. The estate DID NOT give any rights to use any of David Bowie's music or authorized the movie. Also, 37-year old actor looks and sounds nothing like 24-year old David Bowie
Just a piece of shit made against David's will. Please don't watch it if you like Bowie
